g.text: Int. J. Environ. Res. Public Health
Department of Hygiene and Epidemiology, School of Medicine, Athens University,
Occupational Health Unit, Department of Public Health, School of Me
Author to whom correspondence should be addres
The indoor environment in four beauty salons located in Athens
examined in order to investigate the occupational health exposure of cosmetologists to
used in their work. Chemical substances chosen
the number of treatments carried out
entilation. The main VOCs found in the salons were aromatics (toluene, xylene), esters and
terpenes (pinene, limonene, camphor, menthenol) which have a particular
like camphor which have specific properties. Ozone concentrations measured in all salons
than the detection limit of the method in all salons (<0.05 ppm). Carbon dioxide levels
depending on the number of people
